newsitem.title: INDIA: Reliance leads rally in Bombay blue chips.
newsitem.headline: Reliance leads rally in Bombay blue chips.

text.p: Bombay blue chips staged a smart rally on Thursday, with action focussed on market-favourite Reliance Industries after fund buying drove the stock nearly five percent higher, traders said.
Shares of Reliance Industries gained 13.25 rupees, or 4.7 percent, to 296.25 -- the day's high with 7.04 million shares traded at the Bombay exchange.
The stock ended 13.05 rupees higher at 296.0 on the National Stock Exchange in volumes of over 18.11 million shares.
"There has been renewed fund buying in many blue chips," said Kirti Doshi, dealer at Biyani Securities.
Bombay's top 30-share index closed 38.0 points, or 1.03 percent, higher at a provisional 3,723.31, above 3,659.39 -- intra-day high.

"The market has rallied at a time when everyone was taking a pessimistic view," said a dealer at a foreign brokerage. "Funds are keen bidders in their universe of stocks -- multinational, refinery and pharmaceutical sectors.
Announcement of poor company results led shares to a weak start on Thursday, but strong bidding by foreign funds reversed the sagging market trend, traders said.

Shares of Colgate-Palmolive (India) ended 2.75 rupees down at 279.50 after the firm said on Wednesday its 1996/97 net rose marginally to 780.3 million rupees, from 775.8 million in the year-ago period.
Engineering firm Larsen & Toubro rose 2.50 rupees to 206.25 ahead of its 1996/97 (April-March) results due later on Thursday, market participants said.
Larsen said its financial results are expected to be announced by around 5:30 p.m. (1200 GMT) after a meeting of its board of directors.
In a snap poll ahead of the firm's results, analysts from leading securities houses forecast an average net profit of 4,326.50 million rupees, up from 3,886.90 million in the previous year.
Net profit forecasts ranged from a low of 4,186 million rupees to 4,530 million.
